headline: Research in brief  17 January 2013
text: Social Science     Photograph: Danny Lawson/PA    According to new research led by the University of Portsmouth, children would find it much easier to learn to read and write if they were first taught how the English language works, rather than trying to sound out words. Experts at Newcastle University have shown the original kilogram is likely to be tens of micrograms heavier than it was when the first standard was set in 1875. Science and technology     Photograph: Image Source/Rex Features    The hormone-releasing Mirena coil intrauterine device (IUD) is a better treatment for heavy menstrual periods than other conventional medical approaches, scientists from the Universities of Nottingham and Birmingham discover. Researchers at the University of Manchester have found that graphene could help detect the presence of drugs or toxins in the body or dramatically improve airport security. Arts and humanities     Photograph: Lebrecht/Corbis     Research led by the University of the Arts, Loughborough University and Columbia University suggests our growing understanding of the cognitive skills involved in drawing can be put to practical use across various arenas, from the classroom to the training of surgeons. And finally     Photograph: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters/Corbis    UK teenagers without the internet are 'educationally disadvantaged' a major study led by the University of Oxford has shown. The researchers' interviews with teenagers reveal that they felt shut out of their peer group socially and also disadvantaged in their studies as so much of the college or school work set for them to do at home required online research or preparation.
